title: Climbing in North Wales
strapline: From slate quarries to soaring sea cliffs, North Wales climbing serves up proper adventure.
metaTitle: Climbing North Wales: Routes, Guides & Gear | Adventure Wales
metaDescription: Discover the best climbing North Wales has to offer. Routes for all levels, gear shops, guides, and post-climb pubs.
heroAlt: Climber ascending a granite face in the Llanberis Pass, North Wales
introduction:
North Wales, mate, it's not just hills – it's a climber's playground. Forget the manicured holds of your local wall; we're talking about the raw grit of slate quarries, the sheer granite of the Llanberis Pass, and the exposed limestone sea cliffs of the Great Orme. This isn't climbing, it's an experience.

What makes it special? Variety, pure and simple. One day you could be tackling multi-pitch trad routes on Dinas Cromlech, the next bouldering in the Ogwen Valley, and the next sport climbing above the crashing waves at Gogarth. The weather? Unpredictable, like a Welsh rugby match. Sunshine can turn to drizzle in minutes, so you need to be prepared.

Who's it for? Everyone, really. There's beginner-friendly stuff at Tremadog (famous for its sunny aspect) and the indoor walls like Beacon Climbing Centre. But if you're chasing a proper challenge, the Pass and Gogarth will test your nerve and skill. Just remember, North Wales climbing is serious business. Be prepared, know your limits, and respect the mountains. And always, always have a backup plan for that inevitable downpour. Learning about climbing north wales will be one of the greatest experiences you can encounter.

spots.name: Flying Buttress, Dinas Cromlech, Llanberis Pass
spots.description: A classic multi-pitch trad route on immaculate granite. Expect sustained climbing with fantastic exposure. The views from the top are breathtaking, overlooking the entire Llanberis Pass. A true North Wales climbing experience.
spots.bestFor: Experienced trad climbers looking for a memorable day out.
spots.notSuitableFor: Beginners or those uncomfortable with exposure.
spots.parking: Pay-and-display parking at the Cromlech Boulders car park. Get there early, it fills up fast (especially on weekends).
spots.insiderTip: Check the Cromlech Boulders for a warm-up before tackling the route. And bring plenty of water, it's a long day.

spots.name: Dream of White Horses, Gogarth
spots.description: A legendary sea cliff route on the Great Orme. Stunning position above the Irish Sea, with challenging and varied climbing. Expect exposure to the elements. This one’s a north wales climbing must.
spots.bestFor: Experienced climbers comfortable with sea cliff environments.
spots.notSuitableFor: Beginners, those afraid of heights, or in strong winds.
spots.parking: Pay-and-display parking at South Stack RSPB reserve, then a 20-30 minute walk.
spots.insiderTip: Check the tide times! Some sections of the route are only accessible at low tide. Also, be aware of nesting seabirds.

spots.name: Christmas Curry, Tremadog
spots.description: A popular and relatively easy multi-pitch route on Craig Bwlch y Moch (Tremadog). A good introduction to trad climbing in a beautiful setting. Often climbed as two pitches, though it can be three.
spots.parking: Park carefully along the roadside in Tremadog village. Be respectful of residents.
spots.insiderTip: Grab a pasty from the bakery in Tremadog village afterwards. Perfect post-climb fuel.

spots.name: Vaynol Slab, Llanberis Pass
spots.description: A series of easier slab climbs, perfect for beginners and those looking for a mellow day out. Good for practicing footwork. Can be a bit polished in places. Vaynol Slab provides stunning views of the Llanberis pass.
spots.parking: Small layby near the base of the slab. Can fill up quickly.
spots.insiderTip: Combine it with a walk along Llyn Peris for a full day out.

spots.name: Main Cliff, Craig y Forwen
spots.description: A quieter crag compared to the Llanberis Pass, with a good mix of trad and sport routes. Less polished than some of the more popular venues. Often a good option when the Pass is crowded.
spots.bestFor: Intermediate to experienced climbers looking for a less crowded venue.
spots.parking: Park responsibly in the small village of Pentre Uchaf, near the Vaynol Arms.
spots.insiderTip: The Vaynol Arms in Pentre Uchaf is a great spot for a post-climb pint. And check out the old quarry workings nearby.

spots.name: Mur Y Niwl, Great Orme
spots.description: Offers a range of single pitch sport and trad climbs. The limestone is varied, some polished, some sharp. Stunning views of the Irish Sea.
spots.bestFor: Sport and trad climbers looking for a variety of routes.
spots.parking: Park in the Great Orme Summit Car Park, or along the Marine Drive.
spots.insiderTip: Bring binoculars to spot seals basking on the rocks below.

spots.name: Indoor Walls - Beacon Climbing Centre
spots.description: Great for learning the ropes, training, or escaping bad weather. Offers a wide range of routes for all abilities, plus bouldering areas. Full cafe and gear shop on site.
spots.bestFor: All climbers, especially beginners and those looking for indoor training.
spots.parking: Ample free parking at the centre.
spots.insiderTip: Check their website for special events and courses.

spots.name: Indoor Walls - Indy Climbing Wall
spots.description: A popular indoor wall in Llanfair PG. Wide range of climbing grades to suit beginners right through to experts. Caters for both climbers looking to train and those trying the sport for the first time.
spots.bestFor: All climbers, especially beginners and those looking for indoor training.
spots.parking: Ample free parking at the centre.
spots.insiderTip: Great cafe on site for post session snacks.

practicalInfo.weather: The weather in North Wales is notoriously unpredictable. Mountain weather can change rapidly, so be prepared for all conditions, even in summer. Check the forecast before you go and be prepared to bail if the weather turns.
gearChecklist: Climbing shoes - Properly fitted and suitable for the rock type.
Harness - Ensure it fits correctly and is in good condition.
Helmet - Essential for protecting your head from falling rocks.
Belay device - ATC or GriGri, depending on your preference.
Locking carabiners - Several, for belaying and building anchors.
Rope - Dynamic rope suitable for the length of your routes.
Quickdraws - Enough for the routes you plan to climb.
Trad rack - If trad climbing, including cams, nuts, and slings.
First-aid kit - Including blister treatment and pain relief.
Water and snacks - Stay hydrated and fuelled throughout the day.
Waterproof jacket - Essential, even if the forecast looks good.

gettingThere.publicTransport: Bangor and Llandudno Junction are the main train stations. From there, buses (including the Snowdon Sherpa) provide access to key climbing areas.
gettingThere.parkingTips: Parking can be limited, especially in popular areas like the Llanberis Pass. Arrive early or consider using public transport. Park responsibly and avoid blocking access for residents and emergency services.

practicalInfo.safety: Climbing is inherently dangerous. Always climb within your abilities and be aware of the risks. Check weather conditions and tide times (for sea cliffs). Carry a first-aid kit and know how to use it. Leave a route plan with someone. In an emergency, call 999 and ask for Mountain Rescue.

faqs.question: What's the best time of year for climbing in North Wales?
faqs.answer: April to October generally offers the best conditions, with drier weather and longer daylight hours. However, be prepared for rain at any time of year. Sea cliff climbing is best in the summer months.

faqs.question: What grade of climbing is available in North Wales?
faqs.answer: North Wales has routes for all levels, from beginner-friendly slabs to extremely challenging multi-pitch climbs. Tremadog is good for beginners, while the Llanberis Pass and Gogarth offer more advanced options.

faqs.question: Do I need a guide for climbing in North Wales?
faqs.answer: If you're new to climbing or unfamiliar with the area, hiring a guide is highly recommended. Operators like Plas y Brenin and Snowdonia Mountain Guides offer courses and guided ascents.

faqs.question: Where can I hire climbing gear in North Wales?
faqs.answer: Joe Brown's and V12 Outdoor, both located in Llanberis, offer a wide range of climbing gear for hire.

faqs.question: What are the best places to eat after climbing in North Wales?
faqs.answer: Pete's Eats in Llanberis is a classic climber's cafe, known for its massive portions. The Eric Jones Cafe in Tremadog is another popular spot, especially for those climbing at Tremadog. The Heights Hotel offers more upscale options.

faqs.question: Is there climbing in North Wales suitable for beginners?
faqs.answer: Yes, Tremadog and Vaynol Slab in Llanberis Pass offer many suitable routes. Indoor walls such as Beacon Climbing Centre and Indy Climbing Wall are also perfect for beginners to learn the basics.

faqs.question: Are there any sea cliffs for climbing?
faqs.answer: Yes! The Great Orme and Gogarth are fantastic locations for sea cliff climbing offering single and multi pitch routes with breath taking views.

gearShops.name: Joe Brown's
gearShops.description: Legendary climbing shop, stocking everything you need for climbing and mountaineering. Known for its knowledgeable staff and wide selection.

gearShops.name: V12 Outdoor
gearShops.description: Well-stocked outdoor shop with a focus on climbing and mountaineering gear. Offers a good range of brands and expert advice.

gearShops.name: Cotswold Outdoor
gearShops.description: Large outdoor retailer with a wide range of clothing and equipment for various activities, including climbing.

postActivitySpots.name: Pete's Eats
postActivitySpots.description: Iconic climber's cafe in Llanberis, famous for its massive portions and hearty food. A must-visit for any climber in the area.

postActivitySpots.name: Eric Jones Cafe
postActivitySpots.description: Popular cafe in Tremadog, right next to the crag. Known for its good coffee and friendly atmosphere. Perfect for a pre- or post-climb refuel.

postActivitySpots.name: Heights Hotel
postActivitySpots.description: Located in the Llanberis Pass, offering stunning views and a more upscale dining experience. Good for a celebratory meal.

postActivitySpots.name: Vaynol Arms
postActivitySpots.description: Traditional pub in Pentre Uchaf, near Craig y Forwen. Serves good food and real ales. A great spot to relax after a day of climbing.

postActivitySpots.name: The Pen-y-Gwryd Hotel
postActivitySpots.description: A historic hotel at the foot of Snowdon, with a bar and restaurant serving hearty meals. A popular spot for climbers and walkers.

postActivitySpots.name: Snowdon Mountain Railway Cafe
postActivitySpots.description: Located at the summit of Snowdon (accessible by train or hiking), with amazing views. A good option for a coffee or snack.

accommodation.name: Plas y Brenin
accommodation.description: National Mountain Sports Centre offering courses and accommodation. Excellent location for climbing in the Ogwen Valley.

accommodation.name: YHA Snowdon Pen-y-Pass
accommodation.description: Budget-friendly hostel located at the foot of Snowdon. Ideal for climbers and hikers.

accommodation.name: Camping in the Llanberis Pass
accommodation.description: Several campsites are located in the Llanberis Pass. A great option for budget travelers.

accommodation.name: The Royal Victoria Hotel
accommodation.description: A historic hotel with beautiful gardens and views. Close to the Llanberis path up Snowdon.

accommodation.name: Bryn Dinas Camping Pods
accommodation.description: Located a short drive from the Llanberis Pass, these camping pods offer a comfortable alternative to traditional camping.

events.name: BMC International Climbing Festival
events.description: A celebration of climbing, with workshops, talks, and competitions.

longTail: sea cliff climbing north wales beginner
